content.raw:
Are you able to insert the models even though the thumbnails are missing?

You need to download models from the web during deploy in order to be able to use them, running:

~~~
./deploy.sh -m
~~~

This will generate the thumbnails as well. Make sure you don't have gzserver running while deploy is working or you might fail to generate thumbnails. Also, note that generating the database will take several minutes.
content.html:
Are you able to insert the models even though the thumbnails are missing?

You need to download models from the web during deploy in order to be able to use them, running:

./deploy.sh -m

This will generate the thumbnails as well. Make sure you don't have gzserver running while deploy is working or you might fail to generate thumbnails. Also, note that generating the database will take several minutes.

content.raw: Sorry, I should have mentioned that if the models are working and you're just missing the thumbnails, running `./deploy.sh -t` would generate the thumbnails without needing to download the whole database again. Now that you have restarted it I think you have to wait for it to finish though.
content.html: Sorry, I should have mentioned that if the models are working and you're just missing the thumbnails, running ./deploy.sh -t would generate the thumbnails without needing to download the whole database again. Now that you have restarted it I think you have to wait for it to finish though.

It doesn't terminate the script, it just hangs there indefinitely.

content.raw: interesting, the warning msg says that its trying to downgrade from version 1.5 to 1.4. This could mean that the sdformat you're using is likely old. Can you try updating to use the latest sdformat? there is currently a  `libsdformat3-prerelease` deb available to try out
content.html: interesting, the warning msg says that its trying to downgrade from version 1.5 to 1.4. This could mean that the sdformat you're using is likely old. Can you try updating to use the latest sdformat? there is currently a libsdformat3-prerelease deb available to try out

content.raw:
you can also get more debug msgs by going to `tools` folder, edit `gzthumbnails.sh` and append `--verbose` after `gzserver` in [this line](#!/osrf/gzweb/src/a166e0734e7d67bf0c3d91da103962f590b94fd3/tools/gzthumbnails.sh?at=default#cl-13)

run `./deploy -t` again and hopefully it gives more insights on what's wrong
content.html:
you can also get more debug msgs by going to tools folder, edit gzthumbnails.sh and append --verbose after gzserver in this line

run ./deploy -t again and hopefully it gives more insights on what's wrong

content.raw: Ok, this has been a nightmare to try to sort out. I'm using Gazebo with the "gazebo_ros" package for ROS, which likely has something to do with old versions of things being installed. Installing "gazebo_ros" automatically installs a specific version of Gazebo (2.x) that it is compatible with. It looks like maybe the SDF models in the database were updated to 1.5, which is not compatible with Gazebo 2.x? But I can't install a newer version of Gazebo, because then it won't be compatible with ROS. So, looks like I'm pretty boned with this one. Three cheers for backwards compatibility...
content.html: Ok, this has been a nightmare to try to sort out. I'm using Gazebo with the "gazebo_ros" package for ROS, which likely has something to do with old versions of things being installed. Installing "gazebo_ros" automatically installs a specific version of Gazebo (2.x) that it is compatible with. It looks like maybe the SDF models in the database were updated to 1.5, which is not compatible with Gazebo 2.x? But I can't install a newer version of Gazebo, because then it won't be compatible with ROS. So, looks like I'm pretty boned with this one. Three cheers for backwards compatibility...

content.raw:
I had to do the following to get thumbnails and coarse meshes built:

1. Ensure that gazebo is not running in the background.
2. Make sure you are working on a desktop with a windowing system (not a headless server).
3. Add the following to the top of ```tools/CMakeLists.txt```: SET(CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS "${CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS} -std=c++11")
4. Run the command ```./deploy -m -t -c```
content.html:
I had to do the following to get thumbnails and coarse meshes built:

  1. Ensure that gazebo is not running in the background.
  2. Make sure you are working on a desktop with a windowing system (not a headless server).
  3. Add the following to the top of tools/CMakeLists.txt: SET(CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS "${CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS} -std=c++11")
  4. Run the command ./deploy -m -t -c

content.raw:
I recently installed gazebo6
Just had a similar issue to "Warning [Converter.cc:59]   Version[1.5] to Version[1.4]" when roslaunching some ros nodes that were working 6m ago with ROS Indigo + gazebo4.
Problem went away after specifying the gazebo number in the gazebo-ros-pkgs install (otherwise it's still picking up gazebo2 as default or something):
 
```
#!bash

sudo apt-get install ros-indigo-gazebo6-ros-pkgs ros-indigo-gazebo6-ros-control

```

It's now back to working fine. Hope this helps !
content.html:
I recently installed gazebo6 Just had a similar issue to "Warning [Converter.cc:59] Version[1.5] to Version[1.4]" when roslaunching some ros nodes that were working 6m ago with ROS Indigo + gazebo4. Problem went away after specifying the gazebo number in the gazebo-ros-pkgs install (otherwise it's still picking up gazebo2 as default or something):

sudo apt-get install ros-indigo-gazebo6-ros-pkgs ros-indigo-gazebo6-ros-control

It's now back to working fine. Hope this helps !

content.raw:
This error occur because gzserver can't open display.
So, use xvfb.  
`sudo apt-get install xvfb`  
`Xvfb :1 -screen 0 1024x768x16 &> xvfb.log  &`  
`DISPLAY=:1.0`  
`export DISPLAY`  
`./deploy.sh -t`
content.html:
This error occur because gzserver can't open display. So, use xvfb.
sudo apt-get install xvfb
Xvfb :1 -screen 0 1024x768x16 &> xvfb.log &
DISPLAY=:1.0
export DISPLAY
./deploy.sh -t

content.raw: Sei Ueno thank you! This saved me!
content.html: Sei Ueno thank you! This saved me!
